title: Welcome To My Talks Page!
text:
Weclome to my Talks Page!
This at this stage of my career I dont give many talks but I wanted a way to categorize them so that in the future I can reference myself when I have to give another.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis in R
text:
Highlight: Used R, RStudio, and the tidyverse libary to visualize trends
html File Can Be Found Here
rmd File Can Be Found Here
Using R I analyzed a dataset of glassdoor.com data science job postings to see the most common skills, the correlations between these skills, most common industries, and most common states from these job postings. I was able to do this by using the tidyverse library.

title: PowerBI Bank Churn Analysis
text:
Highlight: Used PowerBI to analize a fictional bank’s churn rate
Data can be found here
PBIX file can be found here
PDF of PowerBI file can be found here
In this post I would like to talk about a PowerBI project I did where I analyzed the churn rate of a fictional bank’s customers across different demographics. The key demographics I focused on were geography, gender, age, and membership status. In the dashboard I included elements like slicers so that the audience could interact with the dashboard to better understand the different churn rate across demographics. Specifically, the geography and age breakdown pages both include slicers so that the audience could interact with the page and gain more insights. In the last page of the dashboard I included the three more visuals which I felt best summarized the insights found in the dashboard, specifically the table shows the gender, geography, and age range of different customers sorted by their churn rate. This information along with the count of Customerid, which shows how many customers are in the specific group, can provide insights to the biggest demographics that leave the bank. For some future work in this dashboard, I could review the estimated salary and number of products variables.

title: Welcome to my Project Portfolio
text: Weclome to my Project Portfolio! I try to learn as much as possible about the world of data so you will see machine learning projects, data analysis projects, or whatever I am trying to learn at the time.

title: About Me
text: Welcome to my website! My Name is Samuel Gerken and I am a motivated data science student who has an interest in all things data. I try to make at least one project monthly so look to the top right to find my projects, talks, and links to my github and linkedin! Below are the same links.

title: My First Machine Learning Project
text:
Highlight: Used DecisionTreeRegressor and RandomForestRegressor to create a model which predicts the prices of Soccer Teams in Europe
Link to code on kaggle
ipynb file
dataset
In this post I would like to talk about my first machine learning project which I completed over Summer 2024.
I created the project off of data I found on Kaggle.com and the dataset is on European Soccer Team data. The project sought to use two different machine learning models to try to predict the price of a European Soccer team. The model had an error of 1.16 billion pounds, while it was nowhere close to accurate, it did serve as a useful learning project.

title: Pizza-Dashboard-to-Database
text:
Highlight: Used MySQL, PopSQL, and PowerBI to create, edit, and visualize data in a dashboard.
SQL Here
PBIX file can be found here
In this project I used MySQL to create a database for a fictional pizza place then connected it with PopSQL for querying and management. Then I connected this database to PowerBI so that I could analyize the insights for a fictional manager of this pizza place. Check out my other repository here for more information about how it was created and the data I used in each table of the database.
I get very in-depth into how I created the project from scratch in the followin repository

title: Data Visualization with PowerBI
text:
This talk was with the Data Science and Business Analytics Association at Florida Poly. We created an event where I gave a talk on what PowerBI is, its key features, data transformation and data visualization in PowerBI. Below is the slideshow I used for the presentation and the data I used in the slides

import pandas as pd
:::

input = '/kaggle/input/football-teams-price-prediction/Football_teams_price_data.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(input)


#Setting price to a number
df['Price'] = pd.to_numeric(df['Price'].str.replace(',', ''), errors='coerce')

#setting prediction as the price
y = df.Price

#Viewing the columns to see which I will use for the model
df.columns

Index(['AveragePlayerAge', 'TotalGoalsLastSeason', 'MatchesWonLastSeason',
       'MatchesDrawnLastSeason', 'MatchesLostLastSeason',
       'TotalGoalsConcededLastSeason', 'TotalRevenueLastSeason',
       'StadiumCapacity', 'AverageAttendance', 'TransferSpendingLastSeason',
       'TransferIncomeLastSeason', 'NumberOfTrophies', 'MarketValueOfSquad',
       'AveragePlayerMarketValue', 'YouthAcademyRating', 'League', 'Country',
       'Manager', 'TeamFormation', 'PlayingStyle', 'HomeCity', 'StadiumType',
       'MainSponsor', 'KitManufacturer', 'OwnershipType', 'Price'],
      dtype='object')



#Setting features(columns) which the model will use to determine price
price_prediction_features = ['TotalRevenueLastSeason','StadiumCapacity','AverageAttendance','MarketValueOfSquad']
X = df[price_prediction_features]


X.describe()

from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeRegressor
football_team_price_model_1 = DecisionTreeRegressor(random_state = 1)
football_team_price_model_1.fit(X,y)

DecisionTreeRegressor(random_state=1)In a Jupyter environment, please rerun this cell to show the HTML representation or trust the notebook. On GitHub, the HTML representation is unable to render, please try loading this page with nbviewer.org.DecisionTreeRegressorDecisionTreeRegressor(random_state=1)



#Now I will validate the data
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
train_X, val_X, train_y, val_y = train_test_split(X,y,random_state = 1)
football_team_price_model_validation = DecisionTreeRegressor()
football_team_price_model_validation.fit(train_X,train_y)
val_predictions = football_team_price_model_validation.predict(val_X)
print(mean_absolute_error(val_y,val_predictions))

1523920827.76736



#Error of 1.5 billion isn't too hot...
#I will now build a model with a random forest model


from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
football_team_price_model_2 = RandomForestRegressor(random_state = 1)
football_team_price_model_2.fit(train_X,train_y)
model_2_prediction = football_team_price_model_2.predict(val_X)
print(mean_absolute_error(val_y,model_2_prediction))

1157624027.9997911



#Not much better, but this model has an error of 1.16 billion
